F448812198744081BF791922E996ED52.description: Provide feedback on own and/or peer business plans.

72C47CFCF07E492F83BDCFAFE776D26A.description: Outline an entry level business plan that may include start-up costs, location, customer base, advertising and an exit plan.

E6C60B08ED3B41D783C45A199770C7B5.description: Research and explain the importance of sustainable business practices such as providing quality customer service, following environmental guidelines and employing qualified and certified personnel.

108D2A9F083B454E8F86354ADAD056FC.description: Research the requirements (e.g., registering for collecting and remitting taxes, licensing, zoning, obtaining health permits and registering the business name) for establishing a small business in one’s community.

F66720DD662B403BBA71BCD7BE2AE5A3.description: Investigate the advantages and disadvantages of different business ownership models, including sole proprietorship, partnership and franchise businesses.

A3C1388C91A54385A43FD9CC1F674E4E.description: Classify examples of food service businesses within one’s community as home-based, sole proprietorship, partnership and/or franchise businesses.

8F5CEA112A234D279F499EDC22174E4D.description: Identify examples of foods that may be processed in a home kitchen and sold, in accordance with Saskatchewan regulations.

25CB69C9FEF94FCD9DD3C960BF7166CB.description: Explain the importance of legislation and/or regulations (e.g., The Food Safety Regulations) that govern the food service industry in Saskatchewan.

ED33ABC11A584E89A53CE6E06E4C8F51.description: Examine characteristics and qualifications of successful small business owners in the food service industry.

C98E4549412B455A889AAC5B3CCEAE99.description: List advantages and disadvantages of operating a small business, including a home-based business.

831E9F74913F494681890F94B48911C3.description: Discuss the contributions that small businesses make to the local and Saskatchewan economy.

B2E02D4EF65343CBBBFB6A9D77903A65.description: Investigate small business opportunities, including home-based business opportunities, in the food service industry in Saskatchewan.

B8C69ABBAAC34AB0BF708F6768FDCA0D.description: Small Business Opportunities in the Food Service Industry (Optional)

D97DE666648E4E18B8ACFAE740BE9C6C.description: Develop and/or revise personal and career goals based on the work placement experience.

CDCEC70D16C34DFEB9AB7804346A45F6.description: Prepare a letter, note, card or other communication for the work placement employer, expressing appreciation.

3C45DAB81F574CAE9145F723E6FFA24E.description: Update personal career documentation (e.g., resume, portfolio) following the work placement.

709BFFF27F534BF79078A6589F9EC483.description: Reflect on the attainment of personal and learning goals.

80A952C868DD4F90804A5F5662B64E62.description: Showcase one’s skills and abilities demonstrated during the work placement using artifacts, evidence of skill development and personal reflections on aspects of the work experience such as: hours worked; responsibilities and tasks performed; the importance of attitude towards work and taking responsibility for what needs to be done; details about the entry level wage, salary scales and earning potential; worker rights and responsibilities and the role of the union, if applicable; ownership structure (e.g., corporation, franchise, sole proprietorship, partnership); and, opportunities for advancement at the workplace and elsewhere in the industry.

723CB4A46D30404BB6C08F57A772AD16.description: Relate one’s work placement experience to personal and career goals.

20CBB484C7E14EFFA7A1AA811DE356E4.description: Document knowledge and awareness of employment standards, safety, workplace ethics, rights and responsibilities, occupational health and safety, and networking observed during the work placement.

ECCA97D53B994EB8B481A28A180A0820.description: Document one’s experience using electronic and other tools (e.g., vlogs, blogs, log sheets, reflective journals) to summarize and reflect upon items such as: hours of work including breaks; responsibilities and tasks performed; interactions with the employer, staff, customers and others; company or organization’s ‘raison d’être;’ and, skills developed and demonstrated during the work placement that enhance one’s employability.

E6D58CF2CECE466693E4DA75DE1A88B4.description: Apply relevant skills and abilities during the work placement experience.

2BA4B1694C2046EDB7CA2FADD51B21B1.description: Participate in a work placement experience.

2AA84C33D9F646ED9FDBEBEE9114D5B3.description: Reflect upon one’s performance during the interview.

18239243A44B4E8884DFD2A5CECC72C4.description: Participate in an interview with the employer prior to beginning the work placement.

3807023819034FBB83D047AC3F19DF3D.description: Develop a list of questions that could potentially be asked by the employer/work placement in an interview situation as well as answers to the questions.

EA48B86054E845C797972CF05F4011A3.description: Brainstorm a list of questions to ask the employer before beginning the work placement; these may include: What is my schedule of work hours?, Who is my supervisor?, What should I wear?, When will I be provided with safety training?, What potential hazards might I encounter in the work placement?, Where do I find fire extinguishers, first aid kits and emergency assistance?, What type of safety gear am I expected to wear? Is it provided?, What should I do if I get injured or have an accident in the workplace?, How can I contact my health and safety committee or representative?, Are there any health and safety procedures I should follow?, Who is the first aid person?, Where are safety notices posted?, What should I do in case of a fire or emergency?

06A000A679D54902B5260E8175B1B729.description: Compile an employer information package that includes documents needed for the work placement (e.g., personal career documentation such as a resume or portfolio, permission forms, logs, self- and employer evaluation forms).

16F1CCCB4AA348D1901EAF0D6EB29EE3.description: Develop a procedural guide for the work placement that includes items such as: transportation to and from the work placement; hours of work; guidelines for absence and tardiness; dress code; job description; and, conflict resolution

B8D1E54CD2C84CDC97BE93FFF2038B7F.description: In collaboration with all partners, develop personal and learning goals for the work placement.

8CF7151A54FB47E788D9B9F9DCECA993.description: Research the business/organization to become familiar with its operations.

63FD540F18BE43FA955C8A836B9139AB.description: Explain the roles and responsibilities of each partner (e.g., student, parent, teacher or other school staff, employer) involved in the work placement.

BE39C4BB625B4452A0B71791AAD43D9A.description: Describe and reflect on the three basic rights that all workers have under Part III – Occupational Health and Safety in The Saskatchewan Employment Act, 2019: the right to know - the hazards at work and how to control them; the right to participate - in finding and controlling workplace hazards; and, the right to refuse – work that you believe is unusually dangerous.

AD3992105E0D4A20BA612D7375E2FEB3.description: Discuss establishments (e.g., restaurants, school cafeterias, hospital and long-term care facilities) that would offer menu options to meet the needs of clients and customers.

E62A9C1468A14EEC8B25E74C731455F4.description: Practise safe and hygienic washing of dishes, tools and cookware, either manually or using a dishwasher.

8A94F8BA937B4A269D1723BE742A80FA.description: Identify industry standard personal protective equipment (PPE) such as safety goggles, gloves, footwear, masks, headwear and protective clothing.

98EFFEC987C54E8D812BBA96267C4DC6.description: Discuss the hierarchy of controls as a system for preventing hazards and reducing risk of injury in the workplace, including: elimination - physically removing the hazard; substitution - replacing the hazard; engineering controls - isolating people from the hazard; administrative controls - changing the way people work; and, personal protective equipment - protecting workers with the use of personal protective equipment.

AC5DEEEC7E2C447D97C4673815E93256.description: Research injuries (e.g., strained muscles, cuts and lacerations, slips, falls and pepper burns) common among workers in commercial kitchens.

5547C517BEEA43B2B211EB3087C81459.description: Discuss the importance of safety in a commercial kitchen.

D197A78B08844100A08C5142AEEDE53E.description: Apply kitchen safety and sanitation practices.
